At 23:59 19/01/2005, you wrote:


>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> > Re: egocentrism etc etc
> >
> > Hi,
> >       This is an email that was a long time coming and was far closer to
>the
> > current topics on the group when I started it but...
> >
> >       I have often wondered how it is that real neural networks (e.g. me)
>manage
> > to exploit the "symmetry" in situations.
> >
> >       e.g. in the example of the egocentric vs the global-centric eye,
>the
> > reason the former has a easier time of it is that it has some
>exploitation
> > of the symmetries of the situation built into it.  That is the two
>specific
> > symmetries:
> >
> > 1) that the world retains the same nature as you translate the
>viewpoint around
> > 2) that the world retains the same nature as you rotate the view
> >
> >       (one could call these "relativities" 'cos they are just like the
> > assumptions underpinning relativity...)
> >
> >       The egocentric eye does not have full exploitation of them,
>however,
> > because for any situation that requires considering the situation at
>two
> > points (or orientations) it is as badly off as the global viewpoint.
>  What
> > this means is, if a piece of learning requires the consideration of
>the
> > properties of more than one "position" -- for example a position#1
>where
> > the prey could not see me, and a position#2, where I could eat the
>prey --
> > then the eye can move to one of the positions, and get free
>"relative"
> > processing, but it has no way of performing any simultaneous
>calculations
> > at a second position, except by evolving its own understanding of
>the
> > symmetry the hard way.
> >
> > --
> >
>
>Just to be devil's advocate, are you sure it couldn't all just be done
>by a roving eye with memory?  Maybe you never really do make
>simultaneous computations for this type of thing.  Maybe it's all
>sequential: look at the first perspective, remember it, then transform
>the view and look at the second.  In memory, perhaps both views are
>stored in some kind of normalized reference frame so they can be
>thought of at once.

Hi,

Absolutely!  This is a way in which it can be done, but the discussion was 
already long and complex without adding yet another consideration.

However, using memory in this way does not really alter the case, because 
for memory to do this, especially in conjunction with a general purpose 
"symmetrical transforms" system, it would still need to somehow pass data 
about between general (memory, transformation) and specific (prey-capture 
or chess) modules, again implying some sort of "data bus".

Not that I'm saying I believe that real brains work that way, I'm just 
holding up a set of phenomena:

         - natural brains can learn a concept once and then apply it as a 
module within multiple other learned behaviours

Asking how they do it and then holding this idea of "data busses" passing 
information around between remote parts of the network as a working 
hypothesis.  Note however, that if you have a data bus then storing 
something in a memory module and pulling it back later is vary simple.

Note also, however, that for a data bus to work _at_all_ there needs to be 
a consistent format for the data in both the sending and receiving 
modules.  Which is the competing conventions problem with a vengeance.

However, it does give us a different perspective of the definition of a 
module.  e.g. in a really nicely OO sort of way a module is 50% defined by 
the data formats in its "interface"...

         Ian
